subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Transactions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1690)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many individual transactions with individual members of the public were conducted by each agency in the Minister's Portfolio in (a) 1998-99 and (b) 1999-2000, and if available, what are the forecast figures for (c) 2000-01; (d) 2001-02; (e) 2002-03 and (f) 2003-04.
(2) What definition of transaction is used to determine these figures.
(3) What proportion of these transactions were or are expected to be conducted online.

(4) What was the total cost of administering these transactions for each agency in (a) 1998-99 and (b) 1999-2000, and what is the estimated cost for (c) 2000-01; (d) 2001-02; (e) 2002-03 and (f) 2003-04.
(5) What was the total cost of administering the online transactions in (a) 1998-99 and (b) 1999-2000, and what is the estimated cost for (c) 2000-01; (d) 2001-02; (e) 2002-03 and (f) 2003-04.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: My response addresses the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA), the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) and the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT).
For the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA)

entry.para: An application, whether or not a fee is charged, or a request for service
Approaches to the Department by an individual client
- in person (at Regional Office counters in Australia) 1
- via the internet, including website visits 1

quote.para: 1 To allow analysis, the figures for future years have been rounded up and held steady. Given recent trend information, this is likely to be conservative.
For the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT)
1 Forecast figures are to 31/01/2001 when the RRT is to become part of the ART.
2 Rough estimate only, based on an estimated average of approximately 10 telephone calls per case (8 incoming, 2 outgoing).
3 Estimate only based on total number of hits since inception of Home Page-yearly figures not kept
For the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT)
1 Forecast figures are to 31/01/2001 when the MRT is to become part of the ART.
The second figure for 1998-1999 relates to the Migration Review Tribunal for the period 1 June 1999 to 30 June 1999.
(2) A transaction has been defined as one where a client seeks a direct service from the agency, such as:
. An application for a visa, whether or not a fee is charged;
. An application for Citizenship;
. An application for Review;
. A request for a TIS service;
. Direct approaches to the Department by an individual client either:
.. in person;
.. by telephone; or
.. via the Internet, including website visits.
This definition excludes:
. Ministerial representation;
. Transactions with vendors;
. Transactions with or by third parties delivering services on the agency's behalf eg Community Refugee Support Scheme settlement services;
. Compliance activity; and
. Passenger movements in and out of Australia.

In relation to the processing of an application, some individual applications can be decided on the spot; others require multiple contacts and may take months, involving numerous “individual” transactions with the agency, including:
. Payment of the prescribed fee;
. Advice of change of address;
. Application for permission to work;
. Payment of Assurance of Support bond;
. Attendance at an interview or hearing;
. Provision of documents; and
. Grant and evidence of the visa.
The capacity does not exist within individual agencies systems to provide a break-up of these individual transactions.
Some differences in data exist between agencies, given individual operating environments and availability of data.
(3) For the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA)
We have defined an online transaction as one where the person is not physically present in our office when the transaction occurs.
The projections may be conservative given the increasing use of electronic services, including the Internet, and the Department's efforts to respond to the Government's Online agenda.
For the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT)
Based on the figures in (1) above, approximately 8% of transactions have been conducted online.
For the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT)

At this time, there is no facility for transactions to be conducted on-line. However, work is underway to upgrade the Tribunal's case management system which will allow the development of a facility for on-line lodgement of review applications via the Tribunal's home page.

Given the background of the Tribunal's clientele, it is not expected that a significant proportion of applications will be lodged electronically, though the proportion is expected to increase over time.
(4) For the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA)
These figures are not available. We do not have data that isolates costs relative to transactions with individual clients.
For the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) and the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT)
These figures are not available.
(5) For the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA), the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) and the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT)
These figures are not available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on the 26 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many firms or consortia submitted expressions of interest for the market testing exercise for Defence recruitment.
(2) Was an in-house bid submitted as part of the market testing exercise.
(3) How many firms or consortia were short-listed and on what date was the short listing finalised.
(4) Did the short list include any in-house bid.
(5) What was the nature of the disclosures that short-listed firms were required to make regarding their assets, liabilities and financial contingencies.

(6) Did the Government announce on 23 November that Manpower Services Australia Pty Ltd (Manpower) and Employment National would be invited to participate in a 3 month national trial to assist Defence meet its recruitment needs.
(7) Did Employment National agree to participate in this trial; if not, why not.
(8) On what date did Manpower commence its involvement in the national trial and when is the trial due to end.

(9) Did the Government announce on 29 May 2000 that Manpower was the preferred tenderer for a twelve month contract, with a five year option, to provide Defence recruitment services in Victoria, Tasmania and southern New South Wales.
(10) Has the contract referred in part (9) been signed; if so, on what date did this occur.
(11) Has his attention been drawn to media reports alleging that a former senior executive of Manpower is under investigation for serious fraud.
(12) Was he or his Department aware of these allegations before they were reported in the media; if so, when was this information received.
(13) Is he satisfied that Manpower has at all times made all necessary disclosures to his Department.
(14) In terms of the contracts referred to in parts (8) (9) and (10), what systems are in place to protect taxpayers' funds and to ensure that value for money is obtained.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) 170 consortia submitted expressions of interest for the market testing exercise for Defence recruitment, of which 12 were assessed and short-listed.
(2) Yes.
(3) 4 plus the In House Option team. The process was finalised on 9 September 1999.
(4) Yes.
(5) Participating firms were asked to disclose information about their financial viability and financial capacity, more specifically:
. copies of audited profit and loss accounts, balance sheets and statements of cash flows for the preceding three (3) financial years;
. annual reports to shareholders (if applicable); and
. particulars of any petition, claim, action, judgement or decision, which may adversely affect the respondent's financial position.
(6) Yes.
(7) No. The reasons are commercial-in-confidence.
(8) Manpower is on schedule to commence contractual involvement in the national trial on 1 September 2000, for a period of twelve months.

(9) Yes, however, the announcement was for a twelve-month trial. Manpower are to provide Recruiting Services in Victoria, Tasmania and southern New South Wales for a period of 12 months. Should this trial be assessed as successful, Manpower will be allowed to complete a 6 year contract, including the 12 month trial, to provide National Recruiting Services.

(11) Yes, however, the member of Manpower staff involved in the alleged incident had been removed from the organisation in July 1999, four months previous to Defence requesting tenders for provision of recruiting services.

(14) The Department has ensured that every effort has been made to guarantee greater efficiency and make the best possible use of the taxpayers' dollar. Manpower will be asked to sign a standard Commonwealth contract, incorporating indemnity, insurance and escape clauses. Defence will also utilise consolidated task outcome mechanisms, key performance indicators and output-based payment systems. Defence will compare every facet of the service provider's expected outputs and can tangibly compare these to current processes to ascertain enhancement of service. For example, the service provider will only receive a percentage of payment for a recruit entering basic training, another percentage if the recruit completes basic training and the remaining percentage when the recruit completes training for a trade.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force Base Amberley: Civilian Use
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1705)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister of Defence, upon notice, on 28 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is RAAF Base Amberley being used for any civilian purposes; if so, by whom and for what purpose.
(2) Does the Minister's Department have plans or proposals to use the site for other than RAAF uses; if so what are the plans.
(3) Is the Minister's Department investigating or developing an alternative use for the site; if so, what are the projects.

talker.name: Moore, John, MP
Mr Moore
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) Defence is currently in discussions with Boeing Pty Ltd in relation to the establishment of a facility to modify and maintain Airborne Early Warning and Control aircraft at Amberley. Part of the Boeing proposal includes using excess capacity in the proposed facility for modification and maintenance of civilian aircraft.

In addition, all Defence Commercial Support Program (CSP) licenses have provision for excess capacity to be used for civilian contracts after consultation with and agreement by Defence. There are a number of CSP contracts relating to RAAF Base Amberley currently under negotiation between Defence and industry.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Puckapunyal Medical Centre
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1721)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1363 (Hansard, 5 June 2000), page 16005), how many in-patient beds were operational at Puckapunyal Medical Centre when the original contract was let with Serco Gardner Merchant Pty Ltd.
(2) How many in-patient beds are currently operational at the Centre.
(3) Is the Government considering transferring the responsibility for (a) in-patient services and (b) accident and emergency services from the Puckapunyal Medical Centre to Seymour Hospital.

(4) If the Government is considering transferring some responsibilities to Seymour Hospital, does that hospital currently have (a) any residential medical staff or (b) a designated accident and emergency centre.
(5) How many on-call doctors are currently available at (a) Seymour Hospital and (b) Puckapunyal Medical Centre.

(6) Has the Director-General of Defence Health Service, Brigadier Ramsey, suggested that Puckapunyal personnel could also utilise hospital services in the northern suburbs of Melbourne; if so, (a) which specific hospitals does Defence have in mind and (b) what is the distance from Puckapunyal to these hospitals.

(7) Did the Prime Minister make certain undertakings at Nyngan on 30 January 2000 regarding the continuation of Commonwealth Services and Defence functions in regional areas; if so, will he maintain current services at the Puckapunyal Medical Centre; if not, why not.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (4) See above answer to (3).
(5) (a) Details of Seymour District Memorial Hospital rostered medical staff are not known.
(b) Serco Gardner Merchant has advised that one doctor is rostered to provide on-call services outside normal business hours.

(6) Puckapunyal Medical Centre has only ever been a low dependency health care facility with no surgical capability. Defence has always accessed a wide range of both private and public hospitals throughout the Greater Melbourne area to provide specialist services. The choice of hospital is always based upon best clinical practice and patient needs.

(7) On 31 January 2000 the Prime Minister addressed a community luncheon at Nyngan, NSW. At that function, the Prime Minister said “I don't want to see any further services, government service levels withdrawn or taken away from the bush. I indicated yesterday and again this morning in Bourke that one of the things that I've asked all of my Ministers to do - and I'm in the process of writing to each of them - ... that in any future Government decisions that, in effect, a red light flashes if that Government decision involves a reduction in the delivery or an existing Commonwealth service. It doesn't mean to say you can't find different ways of delivering the same service level”.
The Prime Minister has made clear, on numerous occasions, that proposals to close down significant Defence facilities in rural and regional Australia would also be subject to the same process.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Spouse Employment Assistance Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1729)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 June 2000:

quote.para: (1) What was the allocation of funds under the ADF Spouse Employment Assistance Program for (a) 1998-99, (b) 1999-00 and (c) 2000-01.
(2) What was the actual expenditure in (a) 1998-99, (b) 1999-00 and (c) estimated expenditure in 2000-01.
(3) How many support networks have been established under the Program.
(4) How many employment information seminars have been conducted under the Program and how many spouses have attended.
(5) How many spouses have been provided with assistance through (a) Defence-specific Job Clubs, and (b) general community Job Clubs.
(6) What initiatives has the Defence Community Organisation taken to highlight the employment needs of Defence spouses to employers and how has the success or otherwise of these been measured.
(7) What services does the Job Network provide to Defence spouses and what evaluation, if any has the Defence Community Organisation conducted of those services.
(8) Has Defence conducted an evaluation of the Spouse Employment Assistance Program; if so, what were the findings and recommendations of the evaluation.
(9) What further measures has the Government subsequently adopted to improve the employment position of Defence spouses and what funding has been allocated for this purpose.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

quote.para: (4) 40 employment seminars have been conducted. A precise count of the number of Defence spouses who have attended has not been kept but it is estimated over 1000 spouses have done so.
(5) (a) and (b) This data has not been collected.
(6) (a) In 1998/99 and 1999/00 the Defence Community Organisation:
. Established the spouse employment website.
. Provided access to a SEAP personal computer, printer and scanner in 42 locations for resume preparation and job seeking activities for individual spouses.

. Wrote to large employers in each DCO area to raise awareness of ADF spouses as potential employees and to advertise the existence of the website. Employers are encouraged to advertise vacancies in the employment section of the DCO web site and to access this site to obtain details of spouses who are seeking employment.

. Sponsored and arranged employment information seminars for Defence spouses in most areas. Invitations to these seminars are extended to local employment agencies, including Job Network Members, local Chambers of Commerce and other participants who are appropriate to local conditions and requirement.
. Sponsored limited `work readiness training where a need was established.
. Produced the employment assistance booklet Jobs on the Move.
. Commenced the expansion of the website to incorporate a wider information database.

(b) A reporting framework is currently being developed from the web site server which will provide comprehensive detail of the web site usage, this will provide very valuable detail for both planning and reporting purposes. The server has the capacity to record where usage of the Internet site is emanating from such as individual homes, community facilities (such as libraries) or DCO Internet computer locations. The DCO web site was recently revised and during the first month recorded almost 9000 hits across the individual pages on the site, this type of data will be effectively captured. This quantitative information, balanced with a mix of qualitative data will effectively assess the viability and value of the initiatives over time.

(7) In 2000/01 the Defence Community Organisation will continue the previously detailed services and will fully implement a recently approved enhancement, a referral service to established Job Network Members who can assist with work readiness training/job search assistance. Defence will fund this type of assistance for those ADF spouses who are not otherwise eligible under Centrelink provisions.
The DCO will survey the ADF spouses who use the Job Network services.
(9) It is not intended to introduce further initiatives relating to the employment of Defence spouses until the evaluation of current strategies is completed.

Consent orders, injunctions, compliance program and contribution to the ACCC's costs, against, of and by the TWU.
Transport Workers Workers Union of Australia (TWU

Construction Foresty Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU)
